note: 130; Cyril of Alexandria, Commentary on John, published as P. E. Pusey, Sancti patris nostri Cyrilli archiepiscopi Alexandrini in D. Ioannis Evangelium (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1872), I:531; and Cyril of Alexandria, Contra Julianum, translated in Norman Russell, Cyril of Alexandria
title: central part of the polemic (see the explanation of ­chapter 12 in Cyril of Alexandria, Explicatio duodecim capitum, published as S.P.N
PG77

Accordingly, it would be difficult to argue that Philoxenos is using Cyril as a model for how to incorporate claims about theological epistemology into his polemics. For the few other examples of comments on ineffability, see Cyril of Alexandria, On the Unity of Christ
